Posts.Content: It is the unknown that scares us, but once first session is over you know the actual treatment isn't so bad and takes just over an hour, well mine does, but I do sometimes have wait 3 hours after my appointment time to get into the ward to have it done.  I have learnt to take sandwiches and some snacks with me and a drink, a book or something to do is essential.  Although they do bring tea round if you happen to be there when the trolly is passing.  But your hospital maybe very different with not so long a waiting time.  I have learnt to live with this as they do not rush you when you are having your treatment and some people are in there for far longer treatments than me and probably you, so I know they give me the time when I am there. They will give you anti-sickness tablets and take those as suggested even if you don't feel sick, having the tablets is the reason you don't.  So important.   I also have steroids for 3 days which also act as anti-sickness and keep your appetite up, so again I stock up on snacks, drinks as I find these make me very hungry and I need snacks, albeit as healthy as possible to watch weight, but I do find fig rolls can help with any signs of constipation, and drinking lots helps this too.  I haven't particularly suffered with this.  But as kipper said we are all different and get different side effects and cope in different ways.  Peppermint tea, ginger tea and green tea are fairly refreshing and do help any indigestion or queasy feelings that you may have. My worst side affect apart from been, very, very tired, so short activity then rest or snooze, your body will tell you so listen to it, is my mouth has been very sore in the second week, some ulcers, taste buds disappearing, and a burning hot dry mouth, but lots of mouth washes you can get for this, ask you chemo nurse or your GP who will make sure you have no infections.  Difflam which you can buy over the counter at a chemist is great for taking off the soreness so you can eat and drink easier, this doesn't last long and the more of a routine I have got into the less I have suffered with chemo 2,3,and 4.  Buy yourself a soft toothbrush or a children's toothbrush and tooth paste if it gets too bad, this helps a lot and I use chrosdly (probably not the right spelling)none alcoholic mouthwash also over the counter. So really the best advise is to get tomorrow out of the way, keep a daily note of your side effects so you can plan for the next session, 'cos you will forget, read the normal side effects on all the tablets they give you this helps you not to panic if something is happening that you were not expecting, and as Kipper said report all back to the chemo nurse or oncologist they are very quick to change tablets etc. if necessary.  They will look after you, trust them. One really important piece of advice I got from this forum and I have had many, is to see your first 3 chemo treatments as climbing a hill, once y0u get there the next three are all down hill you are in a good routine.  I had my fourth session yesterday so definitely on the way to the end, of course I have had moments when it all seemed far too much, but you know it is doable and does go quickly, build in some treats for week 3, lunch or coffee with friends or family, visits, nails as kipper says, get them painted black, I do the week before, you will find little things suddenly mean a lot, but still get rest in this week before your blood test. Lots of warm wishes for tomorrow and let us know when you can how it went.   Everything crossed for you.

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline yes I have finished at the end of February, saw the Onc. the week before I had finished and don't see her again until the end of May.   Then go at the end of June for mammogram etc. as it will be then 1 year since diagnosis.    It is a very strange feeling as no further medication to help keep the little blighters away when you are triple neg. so although I had read of people dealing with this in very different ways I was determined not to let it worry me and get my life back on track.   Now great sentiments but not always easy, as Judith said a few wobbly days along the way, I think for me the first two weeks were strange, felt vulnerable and a little sad, though no idea why, my hair is growing well, I have better eyelashes than I had before!  I came to the conclusion that it was the after effects of getting through all the treatment and the realisation that it was all over, as you know I have always been positive and seen the humour in everything, that escaped me a little.    But now after more than a month later that feeling is fading fast. I realised I was just sitting for most of the day, thinking well I have to rest and recuperate, and was feeling worse not better.  So I made myself go out, taking my camera as my friend, didn't matter walking alone if I could use my camera gave me a purpose,  finding going out, walking, chatting, taking photo's I love my camera, has brought a new energy.   Yes it is a little scary as we have no backup medication but we have none of those awful side effects that other women have to deal with, we feel we are on our own to make sure we keep as healthy as possible.    So my only advice would be to give yourself some time to adjust to the fact that your hospital appointments are disappearing and not so intense, we have support still from BC nurses,  oncologists, GP's and the forum so we are not alone.   Then start to build up your energy and motivation, eat well, carry on with drinking  water, sleep well, (which of course means Candy Crush time is diminishing), laugh well and  love well.    And most importantly treat yourself.      I have attached (hopefully) a pic I took a couple of weeks ago, when we were having warmer weather, just up the canal path where I live. Posts.Title: Radiotherapy only day 3

Posts.Content: Hey, I too like to be prepared and organised as it helps me with any new experience.  I have to say at this point Tweedledee that I have only had one round of FEC chemo.  This is what I did.  I have the treatment on a Monday, so the weekend before I went to Lincoln to visit my son and family as my Grandson was 6 and a party was planned.  I ate and drank as normal, had a great Chinese takeaway which I was glad for as now can't have them, so I saw it as an indulgent and relaxing weekend to set me up.   I was terrified of been sick, so I bought a small pedal bin so I could use the inside bucket if necessary and as it has a lid it would be covered.... does this make sense.  I also bought nappy bags and had these under my pillow, by the settee, in my bag, in the car for the journey home, anywhere I thought I might need them.   Over the top probably but made me feel secure.  I bought ginger biscuits, ginger tea, ginger ale, and peppermint and green tea, Dettol,  alongside snacks, so I could eat little and often.  Bottle of water as they recommend you keep hydrated. Here is what happened.  Once home I slept for 3 hours, ate my dinner, slept  woke about 4.00 am ate Weetabix, slept, woke about 7.00 am ate toast.  This was the pattern for the next few days.  By the following weekend I feeling almost normal again.    I wasn't sick, very dry mouthed, light headed, wobbly for a few days, so get a stash of DVD's to watch, it is really important to take the anti-sickness tablets as instructed, I never felt sick with these, but a couple of times I was late taking them and started to have a queasy feeling which was taken off once had the tablets.  So peddle bin is still in the car, nappy bags keep turning up in places I have forgotten I had put them! What surprised me was the need to eat, think it may have been the steroids, I would eat then be looking for the next think I could consume.  I only had these tablets for 3 days so it doesn't last but glad I had plenty of fruit, and other snack to keep the hunger or greed (not sure which)  at bay.  Having grown up as a bad traveller suffering with travel sickness I have learnt to keep eating in these situation works for me.  I am now on week 3 so last night was the first night I have slept through without waking, I have seen this waking in the night as a positive I just get up and read or do something rather than lie there pondering....   I am lucky though I work for myself so can adjust what I do and how I do it so have the flexibility, which you may not have.  The tablets that can cause constipation I only had to take for 3 days, so I made sure I drank plenty of water, ate fruit and ate well which actually worked for me, though drinking plenty of water did mean I woke in the night.  A small price to pay though I think. The second week I got an extremely sore mouth, burning, dry and ulcers.  This is starting to ease now, I can recommend  Corsoldyl and Difflam mouth washes and Difflam spray.  Corsoldyl help prevent this happening and Difflam eases it once it has happened.  I carry the spray with me as when out these last few days I needed to use it and it was easier that using a mouth wash.  I won't bore you with the story of me in a church yard trying to use mouth wash so I could go and eat some lunch!!!  So a spray is helpful x    I also bought milk teeth toothpaste and a soft toothbrush, as normal stung too much. During this week I also had a visit to the hairdresser and had my hair clipped to a No 1 cut, and will be having my nail painted black this week too.  Because losing hair and nails was also a major fear for me, so feel I have done everything I can now on that score. I am just starting my third week before my next chemo and looking forward to a good solid week, get the shopping and meal planning for the week of chemo, prepare physically and emotionally for the sleeping and DVD week, not bad really how many times I have  dreamed of having the luxury of watching DVD's, telly and sleeping.  So if you manage to get to this stage of your reading Dee of my ramblings I hope a small bit of it helps you in your planning.    And remember the end result is so positive that we have to do whatever is necessary to embrace our 'new normal'. Stay positive and happy   Gillie xxx Sometimes you just gotta put on them shoes and dance!

Posts.Content: Hi do hope your chemo is going well.   Sure you know the second week is the most vulnerable for you for catching infection, so as along as your friends Grandchild does not have an infection and then comes to see you all should be well, as others have said you and your visitors washing your hands is an absolute must,  I was also told to have my own hand towel. My BC nurse gave me a whole lots of instructions to follow and must admit apart from a dodgy pasty causing a stomach upset I was fine.   Here are some of them:  wear those skin tight gloves when preparing raw meat, fish etc. easily got from chemist or supermarkets.    Keep away from takeaways, unless you really, really trust them, pate, cream yoghurts, eggs unless well cooked, offal, and wash salads, fruit and veg.   Drink plenty of water and keep away from shop bought water in plastic bottles.  Sorry if you have already been told all of this!!!! I do know people who haven't been told any of this, and been fine, so it is a very much personal choice I guess.   Keep away from 'buggy' people and large crowds, during your vulnerable time, so seems to be if your friends Grandchild is well and healthy there is no problem, see her, enjoy it is always good to see a good friend.    Just be careful, better safe than sorry generally, but don't make yourself a prisoner, chemo is hard enough. Posts.Content: Hi MelBed, this is such a good group to join, full of supportive and very caring men and women who will always take the time to come on and reassure you, answer your questions and just be there when you need somebody to talk too.   What I love the best about this group, although we know the diagnosis of those on here and little bits about their lives, if they want to share, we are all equal and we are all different.  There are no barriers between us in the conventional sense, and certainly no judgements are made. As Bongo said I have been on a similar journey to the one you have started and I am out the other side, I too was diagnosed with triple negative grade 3 breast caner, and I say was diagnosed with, because as far as I am concerned once lumpectomy was over the cancer had gone, and as my oncologist said the following chemo and radiotherapy was a mop up and preventative treatment.  Chemo is horrid but very, very doable, very hard with a 2 year old, you will need to get an army of friends and family around you to support your little one and yourself during this time.  What chemo are you on? I had 6 x FEC, and have seen Mrs Brown's boys, the comedy show in a different light since having this, in fact have just bought my Son a birthday card which says 'Happy Feckin'  Birthday' knowing he will see the joke.   (Well I hope so)   I found the first week the hardest with the chemo, very tired, not sleeping too well, due to the steroids they give you, one tip is to take them early and not after 3.30 - 4.00 pm this helps with sleeping.  I learnt to embrace the not sleeping and used it to catch up on my Candy Crush, catch up TV but I was in th fortunate positive to be able to sleep in the day if necessary.  This does pass and by the second week was sleeping through the night most nights.  The second week you do have to be careful of been around people with colds etc. and you re susceptible to caching whatever is going around, as your white blood cells will be low, though often it is your own bodies bugs that cause a problem as you are not fighting them off as you usually would.   By the third week I was more energised and going out but found I still needed to rest or go to bed early. Drink plenty of water, this of cause can then have the effect of waking you in the night too, but it is important to flush the toxins through your body, and before you next chemo drink water still as this will plump up your veins ready for the  next session. There is a lot more I could say regarding chemo but don't want to overload or ramble, be rest assured everything you are feeling is normal, keep a little dairy this will help you plan for the next session, for shopping, washing, cooking etc.  I managed to do all of those things throughout chemo even if I started the preparation for the evening meal at lunch time, so took it in stages, and tried to make things that would look after them selves in the cooking. The greatest advice I can give you overall is to keep a sense of humour, and see chemo as your friend it is fighting to keep you well and healthy so you have many more years with your little one. Having Grade 3 Triple Negative is scary, as there is no follow up treatment as there is with other types for 5 years, but your team will do everything they can for you so embrace it and Know you too will be through this before the year end.    Continue to ask the questions please 'friend' me if you think that will help as I am happy to share with you. Take lots of care MelBed and know that tomorrow is another day.    xxxxx
Posts.Title: Coping with chemo

Posts.Content: Hi I too have triple negative breast cancer, grade 3.  However I am post menopause, but thought I would add some of my own techniques for dealing with menopause, as I went through this naturally but early in the scheme of things.  I started at 48 - The worse for me was the night sweats and once I had realised this was probably caused by   an adrenalin rush and the wet sheets through sweat went cold very quickly, and I seemed to have a fountain spurting out of the middle of chest, I set about strategies,  I kept a very large bath sheet by the bed, that could go on top of the sheets for the night, baby wet wipes sorted the fountain in a way but did help, also one on my forehead and a fine water spray can also help.  You can buy these but try making one with a very very fine garden spray, if it is possible to buy these.  Laying in bed was no use to me as I had all this spare energy, so I would get up read, drink tea, watch telly depending on the time, prepped for teaching, did some ironing whatever made me feel better, have to say ironing wasn't on top of my list, but did keep it down which took pressure off other days.  and wait for my sleepy head to appear, some nights it didn't so would be up when the rest of the family got up, I would be ok for work, but did need an early night the following night.  This I found for me was far less stressful than trying to sleep when my body clearly didn't want or need....    I eventually got into meditation as I found an hour of this early evening relaxed me enough and gave me enough energy when I got home from work before I needed to cook etc.  This often helped in the night wakes too. I felt I was lucky too, as my children were still at home, I had a good career which still had places to go, and in a fairly good relationship, though although got me through this stage up to a point didn't last forever!  So being younger I felt was a great advantage for the menopause, a lot of the time menopause corresponds with careers possibly at their peak, or waning, children leaving home so can be another step in what can feel like a downwards slope.  Though it isn't as we soon become to realise the older we get.  Though as things have changed economically children are not leaving home so early and with pensions changing careers are becoming longer.   What I am trying to say is see menopause as a natural part of our lives as women, yes you have started yours artificially but it would have happened anyway, and the side affects combined with the side affects and stress of cancer and treatment are a double whammy, but if you can take some control of  menopause  symptoms it may be easier to deal with it.  And remember the money you will save on all those personal items......  Sorry if I have rambled certainly got 'Chemo brain' today took me three attempts to spell symptoms and don't even ask how I got round 'adrenalin' so here is hoping it all makes sense and possibly useful for some.   Big hugs

Posts.Content: Yes it does work Chelsea there are plenty of evidence on these forums to show that, I will be half way after my next chemo on Monday, it will soon go.  Plan the week after with food, easy to prepare and things that you like to eat, be prepared to sleep a lot and please, please take the anti-sickness tablets they give you even if you don't feel sick.  I have and up to now have managed not to be sick at all.  I did get in ginger tea and ginger biscuits just in case, though have enjoyed the biscuits, not something I usually buy, good for dunkin'.  Try and get somebody else to cook for you if possible. Remember the team that are supporting you want the best possible outcome so put your trust in them and try and relax.  I also suggest you get a good mouth wash as your mouth can get very sore and possible ulcers, I used Corsodyl once cleaned teeth  and Difflam when my mouth was sore which numbs your mouth and gives instance relief, pure joy.  Might be worth getting these in in case,  pineapple is good for this too, also little ice lollies. All this will be explained on Friday to you, also ask what foods you can or cannot eat.  Drink plenty of water, they suggest not bottle water but from a running tap. It is not the best Chelsea but all doable, lots of us are going through this, it does mean changing your routine and setting up a new one, but it is not forever.  Please 'friend' me if you want further chats. Lots of warm cuddles for Friday take somebody with you and take something to do.  Take care and positive.

Posts.Content: Oh well done for completing all your treatment.  I am 10 days away from doing the same and counting every day....  well I still need that conversation with the oncologist but have done everything they have asked of me, op, chemo and now rads. with an extra 5 day booster.   I have made the decision, at the moment not to read the cancer survivors handbook unless I need to, didn't want to put things in my head unnecessarily, I do know though that I won't just bounce back and will need time to adjust and recover.   Like you I have pondered about staying with the forum, but know that I won't go this route, it has been so supportive and helpful and I have met another forum user who lives 10 mins. away from me and talk to others, over the UK  that |I wouldn't want these links to go, and  will want to encourage and support old and new.  I have to say it has been a lifeline for me particularly at silly o'clock.    But I can see where you thoughts are based. So Kipper, (I have always liked your user name) you take lots of care, enjoy your new found freedom and be very kind to yourself and those that love you.   x
Posts.Title: All done

Posts.Content: Sorry you are plague by this horrid cough, I finished fec on the 30th December, and got a cough and a tight chest every session, turned out to be the anti-sickness, which they changed for me and it got slightly better.  I also had a runny nose one I couldn't control - difficult at times!  You need to ring your bc tomorrow at the very least your GP, but bc would be best.  As you can tell I am too awake at silly o'clock one of the joys of treatment.  Good luck I am going to watch catch up TV and or play candy crush, seems a favourite on here when sleep evades us. Try and relax and try and drink as much water which may help your throat and cough. Sending you night time hugs.
